answers.author: Andy White
answers.text:
We switched from volunteers at our old location to paid shelvers at our new, much busier location.   I have found any essential task can be supplemented by volunteers but to really get those materials back out in the public area, you need a paid employee.    At our old location, our paid staff ended up supplementing the volunteers (much to their chagrin) rather than volunteer supplementing paid staff.

answers.author: Barbara Pickell
answers.text:
We use volunteers for high demand items, like DVDs and new books, which require limited training.  My experience has been that it is difficult to find enough people who want to do a routine, repetitive and physically demanding job on a regular basis to keep material shelved every single day.

answers.author: David Donaldson
answers.text:
I have worked in cities with both and it can work either way. Paid were justified in a library with very tight space where books had to be repositioned and moved to fit the ones going back on shelf and there was a fear volunteers would not do this as well.  A modified approach is to have volunteers get the carts ready for the shelvers.  Neither library I have been associated with had a hard time getting enough volunteers.

answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
Hey Bonnie,
I parsed through some resources we have here on the Knowledge Network.  It looks like some municipalities have been able to successfully use volunteers as shelvers in libraries, and it is mostly dependent on the training given to the volunteers.
According to this document from the Center for Performance Measurement, Sarasota County, FL was able to effectively use volunteers and bring its visitation rates to extraordinarily high levels: 
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/3182
Another ICMA document hailing from Pendleton City, OR, gives advice on properly recruiting and training volunteers.  It is important to allow volunteers the opportunity to select their own jobs and provide them with specific recognition for their service:
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/7776
While these are not direct experiences from city managers, I hope they give insight into the value of volunteers as shelvers.
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA
